DOC.HEAD: $adv24
For release Sunday, Dec. 24
With BC-Eastern-Then and Now
DOC.TEXT: Here are key events in the Machinists union strike against Eastern Airlines: _March 3 _ President Bush refuses National Mediation Board request to use his authority under Railway Labor Act to delay strike 60 days. Machinists reject Eastern's latest contract offer. Talks collapse at midnight. _March 4 _ Strike begins, canceling almost 90 percent of Eastern flights, stranding passengers across nation, in Caribbean and Latin America. _March 5 _ Few Eastern flights take off as pilots honor the strike. _March 6 _ Eastern idles 7,000 non-union workers and cancels nearly all flights. Airline asks federal judge to order pilots back to work. _March 7 _ Judge refuses to order pilots back to work. Eastern furloughs another 2,500 employees. _March 9 _ Eastern files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. _March 31 _ Real estate tycoon Donald Trump announces he has completed a restructured deal to buy Eastern's Northeast shuttle service for $365 million. The new deal, revised from an October 1988 agreement, provides him with four additional Boeing 727s. _April 6 _ A group led by former baseball commissioner Peter V. Ueberroth announces it will acquire Eastern and a 19.9 percent stake in the System One reservations system in a deal valued at $464 million. Under the deal with Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., Eastern employees would own 30 percent of the airline in return for wage and benefit concessions. _April 12 _ Ueberroth and Eastern announce the buyout proposal has collapsed. Eastern says it intends to reorganize as a smaller carrier serving roughly 50 percent to 60 percent of its pre-strike schedule. _May 3 _ A group led by William Howard, former chairman of Piedmont Aviation, discloses that it is interested in making a buyout proposal for all of Eastern. Chicago businessman Joseph Ritchie already has expressed interest. America West Airlines offers to pay $726 million for Eastern's shuttle and 10 Boeing 757s. _May 23 _ Eastern graduates its first class of new pilots hired since the start of the strike. _May 25 _ Lifland formally approves the sale of the shuttle to Trump for $365 million, after America West withdraws offer because of failure to arrange financing. _June 1 _ David Shapiro, bankruptcy examiner in the Eastern case, dismisses the Howard group's offer. _June 2 _ Eastern announces an austerity program for non-union employees. _June 5 _ Lifland removes the Ritchie plan from consideration. _July 21 _ Eastern submits a reorganization plan to the bankruptcy court. Creditors express approval. _Early August _ The striking pilots vote to continue their sympathy walkout. _Aug. 24 _ Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo says he is considering selling all or part of Continental Airlines, Eastern's sister carrier. Scandinavian Airlines Systems, which owns 9.9 percent of Texas Air, reportedly is interested in buying a stake in Continental. _Aug. 31 _ Eastern abandons an earlier plan to sell Latin American routes, giving it around $370 million less in cash by yearend than first projected. _Sept. 8 _ The striking pilots vote to throw out their leader, Jack Bavis, for proposing that they consider ending walkout. _Sept. 13 _ Lorenzo tells Texas Air shareholders Eastern will turn a profit in 1990. SAS says it has no ``immediate interest'' in buying part of Continental. _Nov. 22 _ The 2,250 pilots still on strike vote to end it. The striking flight attendants quickly follow, leaving the Machinists alone on picket lines. Eastern says few jobs are left because it's hired replacements. _Dec. 19 _ American Airlines announces it will buy Latin American routes and other assets from Texas Air for $471 million. The deal shrinks Eastern to about two-thirds its pre-strike size.
